author: m.kalinin
content: In my perspective observing anything on the canonical chain that pretends to have an objectivity (up to a certain extent ofc) requires a decent amount of social coordination, this was the case with the deposit contract and with the genesis state. Making a round of social coordination on each WS checkpoint looks too resourceful and diminishes the usability of the WS mechanism.

author: arnetheduck
content:
There are several problems with the approach of relying on client teams for this coordination, in general:

* it gives clients devs even more power (they arguably have a lot, already), which in the case of a majority client might lead to a small number of individuals (the devs of that team) to effectively become the arbiters
* it requires a steady stream of releases
* in the case of a fork, ETC style, the model becomes difficult to sustain

nothing of this is relevant *right now*, when the consensus is 100% clear - everyone's still too excited about staking to be making noise - it's the worst-scenario cases of giving clients this power that should be considered, first and foremost - long story short, I'm not sure I want someone knocking on my door telling me to follow their consensus, with profitable arguments to back up their story.
